div.l: When̄ he saugh his tyme softly
He loked vp̄ and doun̄ till he had founde
The Clerkys hors there as it stode bounde
Behynde the Melle vnder a lefsell
And to the hors he goth feire and well
And stripeth of the bridell right anon̄
And when̄ the hors was louse he gynneth to gon̄
Tawarde the fen̄ · there wilde Mares renne
And furth · with · we he · thrugh thicke and thenne
This Miller goth a geyne no worde he seide
But doth his note and with the clerkys pleide
Till that hur͗e corn̄ was faire and well y grounde
And when̄ the mele was sackid and y bounde
This Iohn goth oute and fyndith his hors away
And gan̄ to crie harowe and well away
Oure hors is lost · Aleyne for goddes bones
Stepe on̄ thy fete · com̄ on̄ man̄ all attones
Allas oure warden̄ has his palfrey lorn̄
This Aleyne all forgate bothe mele and corn̄
All was oute of his mynde his husbandrie
What whilke way is he gon̄ he gan̄ crie
The wif cam̄ lepyng Inward with a renne
Sheo seide allas youre hors goth to the Fenne
With wilde Mares as fast as he ma goo
Vnthanke com̄ on̄ his hed that bande hym̄ soo
And he that shulde bettir haue knyt the Reyne
Alas qduod Iohn · Aleyn̄ for cristes peyne
Ley doun̄ thy swerde and y will myn̄ alsoo
I am full wight god wote as is a Roo
By goddis harte he shal not scapyn̄ vs bathe
Why ne haddest thou put the caple in the lathe
Ilhayle Aleyne by god thou is a Fonne
Thise sely Clerkys haue full swithe y ronne
Towarde the Fenne · bothe Aleyn̄ and Iohn
And when̄ the Millere saugh they were gon̄
He half a busshell of her͗e floure hath take
And bade his wif to knede it on̄ a Cake
He seydeseyseyde y trowe the Clerkis ben̄ a ferde
Yet can̄ a Miller make a Clerkis berde
For all here arte · ye let hem̄ go here wey
Lo where they go · ye lette the children̄ pley
They gete hym̄ not so lightly by my Croun̄
These sely Clerkys romen̄ vp̄ and doun̄
